scenario:
PayPal has undergone a transition year to improve its offerings and margins. The company has struggled to maintain rapid growth since the pandemic and faced scrutiny for declining margins. However, under new CEO Alex Chriss, who joined from Intuit, PayPal has taken steps to reignite growth. Chriss has revamped PayPal's checkout options, improved the checkout experience, and enabled one-click checkouts, attracting big-name customers. The company has also become an additional payment processor for Shopify Payments and partnered with Amazon to bring its checkout option to businesses using Buy with Prime.

PayPal is expanding into digital advertising, using its consumer spending data to connect customers with merchants and convert more sales. The company plans to use artificial intelligence to create targeted discounts and personalized recommendations. This expansion could be a significant boost to PayPal's business, with the digital marketing space projected to grow nearly 15% annually by 2030.

PayPal's stock has gained 40% over the last year, and the company is priced at 18.3 times this year's projected earnings and 13.4 times free cash flow, which is on the low end of its valuation since being spun off of eBay in 2015. At this price, PayPal looks like an excellent value stock to buy today and hold for several years as it expands on key partnerships and rolls out its digital advertising business.
